supporting_text: The NAP mentions a Tripartite One-Health Approach to strengthen national AMR laboratory network in human, animal health and food safety sectors.
The NAP includes specific actions in the human health sector, such as improving awareness and understanding of AMR across all institutions and sectors.
The NAP includes strategies to optimize the use of antimicrobial medicines in animal health.
The NAP addresses environmental health through strategies related to waste management and the impact of antimicrobials.
The NAP includes actions related to food safety and hygiene, as well as promoting good practices in animal husbandry.
The NAP outlines regular monitoring and evaluation of the national action plan, including quarterly meetings to discuss progress.
The NAP includes specific activities linked to indicators and targets to help implement the National Action Plan on AMR.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence and antimicrobial use.
The NAP mentions the need for sustainable investment and a budget for the implementation of the action plan.
The NAP includes a Costing and M&E Framework to assist in submitting for annual budgetary requirements.
The NAP proposes the establishment of a National AMR Committee to coordinate actions.
The NAP includes actions to review and update the National Medicines Policy and legislation regarding antimicrobial use.
The NAP includes developing an educational program for schools on AMR and rational use.
The NAP outlines plans for awareness campaigns and training for community leaders and NGOs.
The NAP acknowledges support from WHO and other development partners in its implementation.
The NAP includes actions to develop an AMR surveillance system and strengthen laboratory capacity.
The NAP emphasizes strengthening laboratory capacity for AMR surveillance.
The NAP includes strategies for infection prevention and control and promoting hygiene measures.
The NAP aligns with international guidelines and standards for AMR control.
The NAP includes actions to review and update the Essential Medicines List for antibiotics.
The NAP emphasizes the need for regulations to enforce rational use of antimicrobials.
The NAP mentions the need for collaboration in research and development related to AMR.
